recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian fried apple pies from Foxfire Book 4
recipes.description: Traditional half-moon shaped pies filled with spiced dried apples, fried until golden. Yellow apples make tastier pies.

instructions.text: To dry apples: Peel and core apples, cut into thin slices. Soak in salt water, drain, lay on flat board or pan on white cloth. Dry outside in sunshine for several days until shrunk to half size. Store in sacks in dry place.
To prepare filling: Add small amount of water to dried apples and cook until tender. Mash with a fork. Add sugar and cinnamon or allspice to taste.
Make pie crust: Mix 4 cups self-rising flour with 1/2 cup Crisco and 1 cup water. Work like regular pie crust.
Divide dough into fist-sized balls (one per pie).
Roll each ball into a very thin circle.
Place cooked apples on one half of the circle.
Fold crust over apples and press edges together with fingers or fork.
Make tiny holes or slits in top with fork or knife to let air out.
Put enough Crisco in large iron frying pan to almost cover the pies. Fry until golden.
Alternatively, brush with melted butter and bake for crisp crust.

notes: Yellow apples make tastier pies than red.
The holes in the crust prevent edges from turning up during cooking.
Can be baked instead of fried - brush with melted butter before baking.

recipes.title: Sugared Violets
recipes.description: Crystallized violet blossoms for decoration or eating.

instructions.text: Cook two cups sugar, half cup water, and a dash of cream of tartar.
Stir until sugar grains (crystallizes).
Dip fresh violet blossoms (free from stems) into the sugar mixture.
Place on platter to dry.

notes: Beautiful for decorating cakes or eating as confections.

recipes.title: Steamed Elderberry Pudding
recipes.description: Traditional steamed pudding made with wild elderberries.

instructions.text: Sift dry ingredients (flour, baking powder, salt) together.
Work in the butter.
Add milk and mix well.
Combine sugar, berries, and lemon juice.
Mix these with the batter.
Pour into a buttered baking dish.
Cover tightly and steam forty-five minutes.
Serve with cream.

recipes.title: Dandelion Baklava
recipes.description: Traditional baklava made with dandelion blossom syrup.

instructions.text: Combine nuts with sugar and spices.
Melt butter.
Layer 8 fillo sheets in buttered 9x13 pan, brushing every other sheet with butter.
Sprinkle half the nut mixture.
Layer 8 more sheets and remaining nut mixture.
Top with remaining fillo sheets, brushing top generously with butter.
Cut into 30 squares before baking.
Bake at 375°F for 30 minutes until lightly browned.
Pour room temperature syrup over hot baklava.

recipes.title: Loquat Pie
recipes.description: Traditional fruit pie made with loquats.

instructions.text: Stem, wash, and cut loquats, leaving a few seeds for flavor.
Cook in water covered 10 minutes until nearly tender.
Combine sugar, flour, salt, ginger, and allspice.
Stir into loquats. Cook stirring until thickened, cool.
Pour into bottom crust, cover with top crust, prick or slash.
Bake at 450°F for 10 minutes, reduce to 350°F for 45 minutes.
Serve with vanilla ice cream and rum sauce.

recipes.title: Mulberry Pie
recipes.description: Fruit pie made with fresh mulberries.

instructions.text: Combine sugar with mulberries in a saucepan.
Mix cornstarch with water separately.
Add cornstarch mixture and juice to berries.
Cook over medium heat until mixture thickens and juice becomes clear.
Pour into baked pie shell.
Cool and serve.

recipes.title: Hickory Nut Cake
recipes.description: Classic three-layer cake with hickory nuts.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Cream butter and sugar together.
Alternate adding flour mixture and milk.
Add vanilla.
Fold in nuts and stiffly beaten egg whites.
Divide among three greased pans.
Bake 20 minutes until done.

recipes.title: Hickory Nut Filling
recipes.description: Creamy filling for cakes made with hickory nuts.

instructions.text: Cook sugar, cream, and syrup to 238°F (soft ball stage).
Remove from heat and cool.
Beat until creamy.
Stir in butter and nuts.

recipes.title: Hickory Nut Pie
recipes.description: Southern-style pie similar to pecan pie but with hickory nuts.

instructions.text: Preheat to 350°F.
Beat eggs, add syrup and butter.
Stir in sugar, maple syrup, and nuts.
Pour into pastry shell.
Bake 45-55 minutes until set.
Serve with whipped cream.

recipes.title: Hickory Nut Refrigerator Cookies
recipes.description: Slice-and-bake cookies with hickory nuts.

instructions.text: Cream butter, add egg and beat until fluffy.
Beat in sugar and vanilla.
Stir in flour, baking soda, salt, and nuts.
Shape into two logs, wrap and refrigerate 1-2 hours.
Slice thin, bake at 350°F for 10-15 minutes until golden.

recipes.title: Maple Hickory Apple Crisp
recipes.description: Apple crisp topped with hickory nuts and maple syrup.

instructions.text: Preheat to 375°F.
Toss apples with lemon juice, 1 tsp cinnamon, and 3 tbsp flour.
Layer in greased pan with liquid.
Mix oats, flour, sugar, remaining cinnamon, nuts, and butter until crumbly.
Spread over apples, drizzle with maple syrup.
Bake 45 minutes.

recipes.title: Juneberry Pie
recipes.description: Classic pie made with foraged juneberries (serviceberries).

instructions.text: Combine all filling ingredients together.
Pour into pastry-lined pie plate.
Top with pastry strips and sprinkle with sugar.
Bake at 450°F for 15 minutes then at 350°F for 25 minutes more.

recipes.title: Begonia Tartlet
recipes.description: Unique tart with sour begonia leaves and cream.

ingredients.item: pastry or graham cracker tartlet shell

instructions.text: Chop the leaves and cook in a pot with approximately 1/2 cup water over medium-low heat until reduced to a thick paste.
Stir the sour cream and sugar into the paste.
Transfer mixture to tartlet and bake at 300°F for 30-60 minutes until the filling bubbles gently.
Cool before serving.

notes: This preparation also works with sorrel

recipes.title: Japanese Knotweed Purée
recipes.description: Sweet purée from Japanese knotweed, similar to rhubarb.

instructions.text: Gather stalks and remove all leaves and tips.
Slice stems into 1-inch pieces and place in a pot.
Add sugar and let stand 20 minutes to extract juices.
Add water to prevent scorching.
Cook until pieces soften, adding more water if needed.
Mix thoroughly once cooked.
Season with lemon juice and additional sugar to taste.
Serve chilled as dessert, over vanilla ice cream, or in a pie shell.

notes: Can be refrigerated or frozen for later use
Similar to rhubarb sauce

recipes.title: Candied Eryngo Roots (Elizabethan)
recipes.source_note: Historical wild foraging recipe from eattheweeds.com
recipes.description: Traditional Elizabethan candied sea holly roots, once famous as an aphrodisiac.

instructions.text: Boil fresh roots in spring water until they reach the consistency of cooked parsnips.
Cut lengthwise and remove the pith with a knife.
Peel and soak in fresh water, then wring dry with cloth.
Bundle 3-4 roots together, tying at each end.
Create a syrup from sugar, rose water, and fair water.
Boil bundled roots in syrup until liquid nearly evaporates.
Shake in basin to distribute syrup coating.
Dry by fire and store in boxes.

notes: Famous in Colchester, England in Elizabethan times
Considered an aphrodisiac

recipes.title: Surinam Cherry Chiffon Pie
recipes.description: Light and airy chiffon pie with tropical Surinam cherries.

instructions.text: Soften gelatin in cold water.
Beat egg yolks with half the sugar, add fruit pulp.
Cook over medium heat until thick, stirring constantly.
Add softened gelatin and stir until dissolved. Cool.
Whip egg whites until frothy, gradually add remaining sugar, beating until peaks form.
Fold whites into cherry mixture.
Fill pie shell and chill until firm.
Top with whipped cream before serving.

notes: Only use ripe berries - one unripe berry can taint the rest
Select deep blood-red fruits

recipes.title: Carrot Pudding
recipes.source_note: Traditional steamed pudding from Foxfire collection
recipes.description: A moist, spiced steamed pudding made with grated carrots.

instructions.text: Mix grated carrots and potatoes with melted butter.
Sift together flour, sugar, soda, and spices.
Add dry ingredients to carrot mixture.
Fold in raisins.
Pour into greased pudding mold or can.
Steam for 2 hours.
Serve warm with hard sauce or cream.

notes: Can be made ahead and resteamed to serve
Traditional Christmas dessert

recipes.title: Dried Apple Cake
recipes.source_note: Traditional cake using preserved dried apples
recipes.description: A dense, moist spice cake made with reconstituted dried apples.

instructions.text: Soak dried apples in water overnight, then cook until soft. Drain and mash.
While hot, stir in molasses. Let cool.
Cream butter and sugar, add eggs.
Sift flour with soda and spices.
Add flour mixture alternately with buttermilk.
Fold in apple mixture.
Pour into greased tube pan.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 45-50 minutes.

notes: Dried apples were preserved each fall for winter baking
Very moist - keeps well

recipes.title: Tame Gooseberry Pie
recipes.description: A sweet-tart pie made with tame (cultivated) gooseberries.

instructions.text: Wash gooseberries and remove stems and blossom ends.
Mix sugar and flour, toss with berries.
Pour into pastry-lined pie plate.
Dot with butter.
Cover with top crust, seal and flute edges, cut vents.
Bake at 425°F (220°C) for 15 minutes, reduce to 350°F (175°C) for 30 minutes more.

notes: 'Tame' refers to cultivated berries vs wild ones
Tart and refreshing

recipes.title: Scuppernong Pie
recipes.description: A unique Southern pie made with native scuppernong grapes.

instructions.text: Heat grapes in saucepan.
Add salt, then cream together butter, sugar, flour, and egg.
Pour butter mixture over grapes.
Pour all into uncooked pie shell.
Lattice top with pastry strips.
Bake one hour at 300°F (150°C).

notes: Scuppernongs must be seeded before using
Low and slow baking creates best texture

recipes.title: Blackberry Flummery
recipes.description: A chilled fruit pudding thickened with cornstarch, a traditional English-American dessert.

instructions.text: Cook berries with water, sugar, salt, and cinnamon until syrupy.
Mix cornstarch with a little cold water to make a paste.
Stir cornstarch paste into berry mixture.
Simmer until thick.
Chill before serving.

notes: Flummery is an old English dessert brought to Appalachia
Serve with cream if desired

recipes.title: Blackberry Roll
recipes.description: A rolled biscuit dough filled with blackberries and honey, baked in a pool of berries.

instructions.text: Roll biscuit dough to 1/3-inch thickness.
Brush with softened butter.
Mix half the berries with cinnamon and honey, spread on dough.
Roll up like a jelly roll.
Place in baking pan surrounded by remaining berries mixed with sugar.
Bake 30 minutes at 425°F (220°C).

notes: The surrounding berries create a sauce while baking
Serve warm with cream

recipes.title: Wild Blueberry Cobbler
recipes.description: A rustic cobbler made with wild blueberries and biscuit-style topping.

instructions.text: Cook berries 15 minutes over medium heat with sugar.
Make dough with flour and shortening, roll thin.
Cut dough into pieces and place on top of berries.
Boil briefly, then bake until crust browns.

notes: Wild blueberries are smaller but more flavorful
Serve warm with cream

recipes.title: Blueberry Fritters
recipes.description: Light, fried dough balls studded with blueberries and dusted with sugar.

instructions.text: Mix biscuit dough with beaten egg and sugar.
Fold in blueberries.
Heat grease in deep pan.
Drop batter by spoonfuls into hot grease.
Turn until brown on all sides.
Drain and sprinkle with sugar.

notes: Don't crowd the pan - fry in batches
Serve immediately while hot

recipes.title: Blueberry Crisp
recipes.description: Fresh blueberries topped with a buttery oat crumble.

instructions.text: Place blueberries in baking dish and toss with white sugar.
Cream butter with brown sugar.
Blend in flour and oats.
Spread topping over berries.
Bake until topping is golden and berries bubble.

notes: Can add a pinch of cinnamon to topping
Serve warm with vanilla ice cream

recipes.title: Huckleberry Cake
recipes.description: A rich butter cake loaded with wild huckleberries.

instructions.text: Cream butter with sugar.
Add flour alternately with egg yolks.
Add milk, baking powder, and vanilla.
Fold in huckleberries.
Bake in loaf pan at 350°F for 45 minutes to one hour.

notes: Wild huckleberries have more intense flavor than blueberries
Toss berries in a little flour to prevent sinking

recipes.title: Elderberry Pie
recipes.description: A deep purple pie made with wild elderberries.

instructions.text: Make thin pastry crust and bake before adding filling.
Mix elderberries with cornstarch and sugar.
Pour into cooked crust.
Bake 30 minutes at 325°F (165°C).

notes: Never eat red elderberries - only black/blue varieties are safe
Pre-baking the crust prevents soggy bottom

recipes.title: High Bush Cranberry Flower Fritters
recipes.source_note: From eattheweeds.com - High Bush Cranberry article
recipes.description: Flowers dipped in pancake batter and fried.

instructions.text: Harvest high bush cranberry flowers.
Dip flowers in pancake batter.
Fry until golden and batter is cooked through.

notes: Berries taste better after one or two frosts
Berries make excellent jelly without added pectin
Use orange zest to enhance berry flavor

recipes.title: Hickory Nut Cake
recipes.attribution: Foxfire Book of Wild Plant Foods
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Wild Plant Foods
recipes.description: Rich layer cake studded with native hickory nuts.

instructions.text: Cream butter and sugar; beat in eggs one at a time.
Mix flour and baking powder.
Add dry ingredients alternately with milk; stir in vanilla.
Fold in hickory nuts.
Pour into 2 greased 9-inch pans. Bake at 350°F for 30-35 minutes.

notes: Hickory nuts have rich, buttery flavor similar to pecans

recipes.title: Hickory Nut Pie
recipes.attribution: Foxfire Book of Wild Plant Foods
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Wild Plant Foods
recipes.description: Similar to pecan pie but made with foraged hickory nuts.

instructions.text: Beat eggs; stir in sugar, corn syrup, butter, and vanilla.
Spread hickory nuts in pie shell.
Pour filling over nuts.
Bake at 350°F for 50-60 minutes until set.

notes: Cover edges with foil if browning too quickly

recipes.title: Wild Hazelnut Cookies
recipes.attribution: Foxfire Book of Wild Plant Foods
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Wild Plant Foods
recipes.description: Crisp butter cookies with toasted wild hazelnuts.

instructions.text: Cream butter and sugars; beat in egg.
Mix flour and baking soda; stir into creamed mixture.
Fold in hazelnuts.
Drop by spoonfuls onto greased baking sheet.
Bake at 375°F for 10-12 minutes until edges are golden.

notes: Toast hazelnuts in dry skillet to enhance flavor

recipes.title: Fried Apple Pies
recipes.description: Individual hand pies filled with spiced cooked dried apples, fried until crispy.

instructions.text: Add small amount of water to dried apples and cook until tender.
Mash with fork. Add sugar and cinnamon or allspice to taste.
Make crust: Mix flour, 1/2 cup Crisco, and water like regular pie crust.
Divide dough into fist-sized balls. Roll each very thin into a circle.
Place cooked apples on one half. Fold crust over and press edges with fork.
Poke small holes with fork to let air escape.
Heat Crisco in large iron frying pan until enough to almost cover pies.
Fry pies until golden on both sides.

notes: Yellow apples make tastier pies.
Can be baked instead - spread melted butter on top for crisp crust.

recipes.title: Bleached Apple Pie
recipes.description: Apple pie made with sulfur-bleached dried apples that taste like fresh apples.

instructions.text: Place bleached apple pieces in uncooked pie crust.
Add butter, sugar, and cinnamon to taste.
Cover with pastry strips or second crust if preferred.
Bake at 350°F for 30-35 minutes or until crust is golden brown.

notes: Bleached apples taste remarkably like fresh apples.
Use minimal water when cooking - water brings back sulfur taste.
